docs.lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the New York-based leveraged buyout firm, is no longer involved in the effort to inject badly needed capital into Oxford Health Plans, the troubled health maintenance organization, people close to the talks said yesterday. Up until yesterday, Kohlberg had been believed to be actively negotiating with Oxford along with another investment firm, Texas Pacific Group, which is now said to be moving ahead with the financing itself. It is not known whether Texas Pacific will invite other partners to help with the financing, the people said.

headline.main: Rescue Plan for Oxford Health Hits Snag

docs.abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co is no longer involved in effort to inject badly needed capital into Oxford Health Plans; Texas Pacific Group is moving ahead with financing; it is not known wither Texas Pacific will invite others to help with financing; 'employment-related' issues with new management that were unresolved ended Kohlberg's involvement (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 United Nations Chief Reaches Deal With Iraq President Saddam Hussein of Iraq met with Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General, and agreed to lift his ban on arms inspections at so-called presidential properties, a spokesman for Mr. Annan said. The agreement could avert another American attack on Iraq and recharge the arms inspection process that was put in place after the Persian Gulf War. A1 Senior Clinton Administration officials warned that deeds, not words, were required to resolve the crisis with Iraq. They said they would withhold judgment on the import of Mr. Annan's visit to Baghdad until he returned on Tuesday with details. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans, one of the New York region's largest health maintenance organizations, is close to announcing that it will make sweeping changes to its top management and that it has raised more than $600 million in badly needed capital, according to people involved in the negotiations. The deal could be announced as early as today, but negotiations were continuing late last night and several issues were still unresolved.

headline.main: Sweeping Changes Said to Be Near for Oxford

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans is close to announcing that it will make sweeping changes to its top management and that it has raised more than $500 million in badly needed capital; Stephen F Wiggins is expected to step down as chairman and Norman C Payson is expected to be named chief executive (M)

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and LAURA M. HOLSON

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE day last month, determined to buy locally in his new neighborhood, Philip Reed, a fresh member of the City Council, walked across East 116th Street from his office and ordered a sandwich at the back of a narrow little deli. The man behind the counter said he could make no sandwiches because there had been no bread delivery that day. Never shy with advice, Mr. Reed explained how easy and profitable it would be to cross the street to the local supermarket and buy a few loaves. Writ small, it was exactly the kind of economic connections he wants to help make in the Eighth District, which includes chunks of East Harlem, the Upper West Side and the South Bronx.
docs.abstract: Robert Lipsyte interview with Philip Reed, lifelong advocate and agitator on discrimination, housing and HIV issues and freshmen City Councilman from district that takes in parts of East Harlem, Upper West Side and South Bronx; Reed, who is child of interracial marriage, gay and HIV positive, decided to seek office after completing 18 months of chemotherapy for bone-marrow cancer; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sarah Townsend Walker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Dirck Walker of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to David Allen Kiefer, the son of Robert H. Kiefer of Manhattan and the late Doris Kiefer. The Rev. R. John Nelson officiated at a nondenominational service at the 200 Fifth Avenue Club in Manhattan. The bride is a social worker at the Jennie Knauff Children's Center in the Bronx. She graduated from Columbia University and received a master's degree in social work from Fordham University. Her father is a director at the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda. Her mother, Katherine Walker, now retired, taught infants and young children at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda.

docs.lead_paragraph: Roberta Kraft is $38,700 in debt. She owes money on her Visa card. She owes money on her American Express card. She owes money to her parents and to her best friend from college. She and her husband have not bought new clothes in two years and live in a cramped one-bedroom apartment because they have spent all their discretionary income -- and a good chunk of their future earnings -- in a single pursuit: trying to have a baby. In her still unsuccessful quest, Ms. Kraft has economized in ways she never imagined. She bought fertility drugs from a pharmacy in Mexico because they were cheaper than those sold in her Upper East Side neighborhood. She withdrew money from a retirement account, paying steep penalties. She sold a pair of diamond earrings she had inherited from her grandmother, tearfully rationalizing that her grandmother would have given her blessing.

headline.main: Calling Infertility a Disease, Couples Battle With Insurers

docs.lead_paragraph: TWICE a month, Elizabeth Genel sits down at the dining table in her seaside condominium to face a small mountain of bills. Fortified with a Pop Tart and a Diet Coke, she makes short work of the stack, reducing it to nothing in 60 minutes flat. At the same time, unfortunately, she also levels the family checking account. When the checks come in, ''there's $4,000 or so in the bank,'' she said. But after the bill-paying sessions, ''there's only $100.''

headline.main: Until Ed McMahon Calls, They Need to Slice Debt

docs.abstract: Article in series Fresh Start, periodic look at crossroads of personal finance; focuses on heavy debt carried by Mark Nyman, lawyer, and his wife, Elizabeth Genel, who owns cosmetics shop; much of debt is from education loans; planner Karen Altfest suggests financial plan to cut expenses and debt; table; photo (M)

Philip Lathrop said that health care providers should do more to alleviate pain and that hospitals should give their patients more privacy and amenities, including double beds, VCR's and access to large video libraries.

headline.main: What Patients Want From Their Hospitals

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past, i've advocated vigilantism (read ''eggs'') as the best weapon against car alarms and other noise pollution, but clearly this strategy isn't working. While crime has dropped, noise complaints to the city have risen sharply. Noise is easily the most common quality-of-life lament. City officials have recently increased the fines for noise polluters, but the new penalties aren't likely to do much good, either. Anti-noise zealots require better weapons. We must unleash the three most powerful social forces on the planet today: capitalism, environmentalism and the determination of New York parents to get their children into the right schools. The first step is to turn street noise into money. The city's honking horns, unmuffled motorcycles and booming stereos represent a vast mother lode waiting to be mined. On any given day, it's probably safe to assume that 10 percent of the 2.5 million motorists in New York City honk their horns, which is illegal unless there's an emergency. If each of the 250,000 honkers merely paid the minimum fine, $220, the city would reap more than $50 million. Add in the stiffer fines for repeat offenders (serial honkers can be fined as much as $2,625), plus the revenue from the many other noise infractions, and the city could gross $100 million a day, more than it collects through all its taxes.

headline.main: The Big City; Calling All Noisebusters

docs.abstract: John Tierney article says noise is quite easily most common quality-of-life ailment in New York City and that anti-noise zealots need better weapons to combat it; says city could turn street noise into money by levying stiff fines on offenders; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MIRIAM SCHWARZCHILD likes to say she practices the second-oldest profession: midwife. Her mission is to help pregnant women have babies at home, and she is one of only three nurse-midwives in the city who works exclusively on home births. A registered nurse with two years of additional training, she spends most days traveling around in her Honda Civic examining and counseling pregnant women. Her phone may ring at any time, usually in the early hours of the morning, and she is off to tend another client in labor.
docs.abstract: Miriam Schwarzchild, one of New York City's three professional midwives, makes house calls to women in Brooklyn who want to have their babies at home; must contend with insurance companies that are slow to reimburse her, hospitals that are reluctant to admit emergency cases, doctors who do not want to act as consulting physicians and malpractice insurance rates so high that she does without it; photo (M)
